About This Game

Band of Drones keeps the basic mechanics of traditional turn based squad tactics gameplay and goes beyond it with character and weapons development.

Join the fight for the underground riches of planet Crixius! The Zentris have already placed their drones around several locations, you need to infiltrate their outposts and kick them out of there!

Features

  • Manage a squad of 12 drones, each with their own set of class specifications and powers
  • Evolve your drones along your campaign, upgrading to their powers and weapon handling capabilities
  • Select a squad of 6 drones before each battle
  • Drones gain experience points for upgrades, according to their performance in battle
  • Purchase new weapons and upgrade the ones you have, from a selection of cannons, missile launchers and laser guns
  • Purchase mods for your weapons to improve their performance
  • Different mission goals such as Purge and Withdraw, Assassination, Object Recovery, Destroy Structure, Protect Structure
  • Up to 4 player local co-op mayhem
  • Play in skirmish or story based campaigns over 4 scenarios
READ MORE

System Requirements

    Minimum:
    • OS: Windows 7 or higher
    • Processor: 1 Ghz or faster
    • Memory: 1 GB RAM
    • Graphics: Intel HD Graphics 4000 and higher, ATI Radeon HD-Series 4650 and higher, Nvidia GeForce 2xx-Series and higher
    • DirectX: Version 9.0c
    • Hard Drive: 200 MB available space
    • Additional Notes: Requires Java 8 or higher (www.java.com)

Recommended
8.9 hrs on record
Posted: March 31
8/10 Great for the price, but has a feeling that more refinement is in the works
If you're feeling nostalgic for Lazer Squad then grab some BoD action. This is one of those simple to pick up but deeper and more nuance-ey than it first appears kinda games, and hit all the buttons for remembering old TBS games on the Amiga.
Games like this are the reason for Greenlight. I first became aware of this game in a very early version first submitted to GL a long time ago. Since then I've been following it with interest and made a rare Day-1 Full -Price purchase.

unseen4ce
387 products in account
2 reviews
Recommended
0.9 hrs on record
Posted: April 1
The game would not track game time when first released.

I enjoy sending scouts forward, disrupting enemy weapons and flipping barriers to secure a room. The barriers are force-fields which allow units and damage to only pass one way. Often you have to be careful when entering a space as you will not be able to see if there are enemies within.

It is like a maze, uncovering rooms as you move along the best route you can see.

I like that the units have different benefits, so I often split my band ...each with a scout and an assault drone. The scout moving forward and disrupting enemy weapons/flipping barriers with the assault then following to destroy enemy units. Heavies are good for clearing heavily defended rooms.

I like that the game is side-view rather than top-down. You have to consider which rooms to advance into, cover, barriers, sight etc. It just seems like a more effective way to present an area than top-down, reagardless; it works very well for this game.

I like the backgrounds.

You can upgrade drones to have different abilities or fulfil certain tasks. I always unlock hacking and pick the best disrupter for scouts and increase clip capacity and unlock mines for the assaults. Accuracy improvement would be a good idea for heavies.

A really fun strategy game.

Was this review helpful? Yes No Funny
5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
Dad's Gaming Addiction
930 products in account
328 reviews
Recommended
1.8 hrs on record
Posted: April 3
This is a pretty tough little game, even on the "easy" difficulty setting. Essentially, you have a bunch of drones at your disposal, six of which you'll pick to go out and do the next mission. Some are "assault", some are "heavy", and some are "precision" (dictating their stats and weapon of choice). Combat is turn-based and is similar to XCOM, albeit a bit more simplified. Some things do bug me about it...one being that the stationary lasers scattered around the levels can shoot through walls and barriers going the opposite direction. I also don't like that right click activates/fires your weapon...it just felt more natural for it to deselect the unit you have selected. I've shot my own drones by accident more than once because of it. Despite these small problems, the game is fairly enjoyable. Missions take 15-30 minutes a piece, longer if you're overly cautious about your moves, so there's a lot of play time here if you stick with it. You can also upgrade your drones via credits and tech points, with each having its own bank of tech points to spend. Give it a look if you're in the mood for a simplified (but still challenging) XCOM-esque game.
